all_paragraphs: This series is based on the Data Science Specialization offered by John Hopkins University on Coursera. The articles in this series are notes based on the course, with additional research and topics for my own learning purposes. For the first course, Data Scientist Toolbox, the notes will be separated into 7 parts. Notes on the series can also be found here.

An important tenet in the Scientific field is that unfalsifiable theories don’t exist, in other words, there isn’t something called scientific proof. What standardizes and evaluates a scientific theory is an evidence. More + better evidence = better scientific theories and vice versa. That said, all scientific knowledge we have today is tentative, which means they’re subject to confirmation and are conjectures (we do our best to understand the world around us, and form theories about them, but they’re not final and can be disproved.)

In Statistics, it’s the same story. You can’t prove with 100% certainty that, e.g it will rain tomorrow at 1 pm, or who’s going to win the election. All statistical tests do is assign a certain probability to the data at hand and indicates the likelihood that the results are from random fluctuations in sampling (reference).

That said, this article will be focusing on significance testing, explaining what p-value is with examples, and how it’s being exploited (p-hacking) in the research field, something is known as the reproducibility crisis.
P-value tells you the odds that a result occured might be of random chance.
To get a more concrete idea of what p-values are, we’ll look at it from a research point of view, that is how it is utilized in statistical analyses or tests — significance testing.
But first, the terms you have to know about are:

Let’s say an experiment is conducted to deduce whether listening to classical music improves focus. To do so, they assign 100 people to sit in a room, and they’re required to do a concentration test whilst wearing headphones with classical music playing. Then, they have another 100 people who participate in the said test without any music. The results of both of these groups are then compared.
Null hypothesis = no difference between classical music vs no classical music
Alternative hypothesis = the opposite basically, there’s a difference …

To prove that listening to classical music increases focus, the experimenters must be able to reject the null, which is usually this big hurdle that researchers must clear through. If they’re unable to do so, that is, there isn’t enough evidence or data to reject it.
In this case, let’s say the experimenters did statistical analyses on the data, and arrive at a very small p-value, they rejoice and publish papers on the topic.
So what does a small (significant) p-value mean again? Here are a few key points

If you think about it, if achieving a p-value of fewer than 0.05 means validating one’s research, and allows them to publish it on papers, it’s very tempting to intentionally hack at that value in one’s favor, and that’s exactly what happened.

Very briefly, this crisis is about researches and experiments in the scientific field having to achieve the golden number of <0.05, which incentivized people to intentionally tweak certain conditions in their favor. This is called p-hacking.
P-hacking also can be related to Big Data and better technology we have today, which allows these tests to be done rapidly.
To see an example of P-hacking in action, check out FiveThirtyEight’s great article which has a live working example that you can play with.

Just a simple example of where you might encounter p-values here’s an example of a linear regression model using the Boston Dataset, along with that is the F-statistics of the model which contains the p-values.
This image above is showing the F-statistics of the significance test using the summary() function.

Prerequisites for this significance test include that the error term, ϵ in the model is independent of x, and is normally distributed, with zero mean and constant variance. And setting the significance level at .05

Briefly put, if you look at the bottom right, you’ll see p-value < 2.2e-16 . This means the p-value is a lot less than 0.05, which means we can reject the null hypothesis that β = 0. Hence, there is a significant relationship between the variables lstat and mdev in the linear regression model.

By the same vein, p-values also help determine whether the relationships observed in the sample exists in the larger population as well. Thus, if p-values are statistically significant, there is evidence to conclude that the effect exists at the population level as well.

Of course, p-values merely tells you that there’s a correlation. To tell how well your model fits the data, that’s where the R-squared values come in. Moreover, residual errors are the “errors” in your model (distance between the regression line and data point) and F-statistics is simply comparing the joint effect of the variables (the higher the better). All these are crucial elements in interpreting your hypothesis testing.

More about the above regression in my kaggle notebook. If you want a complete introduction, check out this article. And another article about interpreting P-values and coefficients in Regression Analysis here.

Consciousness — a product of the mysterious, ineffable mechanism underlying the transmission of electrical signals between 86 billion neurons in our brains — gifted humankind with the ability to have subjective experience about our surroundings, to ponder about the past, present, and future, to question about the world, to fathom the unfathomable.

Our incredible minds gave birth to many amazing discoveries and breakthroughs, and our many ways of reasoning about the world helped us simplify the complex around us. But with the rise of information and technology that speeds up connectivity and connects the world together comes sacrifice in truth and the plague of misinformation. Thus, we have to understand that all of us have biases, and we are inclined to act based on incentives, and our attention in this modern world is constantly being capitalized by technology.

To conquer that, we have to be conscientious about our actions, reflect on them, and learn from our mistakes. We must learn to set our attention on what matters, pursue what is meaningful and not what is expedient, surround ourselves with good people, and act not out of selfishness, but for the greater good of society, and the world.
Jordan Ellenberg, author of “How Not to Be Wrong: The Power of Mathematical Thinking” has great insights on significance testing:
The significance test is the detective, not the judge. The provocative and oh-so-statistically-significant finding isn’t the conclusion of the scientific process, but the bare beginning.
And a summary of the null hypothesis:
To end this article here’s some truth about what statistics is.
The purpose of statistics isn’t to tell us what to believe, but to tell us what to do. Statistics is about making decisions, not answering questions. — Jordan Ellenberg
